TopicTitle: [1.12.x] Cryogenic Engines: Liquid Hydrogen and Methane Rockets! (Jan 22, 2022)

Articles.Content:
**Here's version 0.4.3**

- Marked for KSP 1.2.1
- Updated <abbr title="Module Manager (mod)">MM</abbr> to 2.7.4
- Updated CRP to 0.6.3
- KPBS <abbr title="In-Situ Resource Utilization">ISRU</abbr> now produces LH2 (thanks Wyzard256)

I feel compelled to use these not only because they're fun to use but also due to the amazing plumes (hoping that's the right word for what comes out of the engine) ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif ":D")

>

> 
> 
> [@Stratickus](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/167609-stratickus/) I got it working, It seems like it was a <abbr title="Module Manager (mod)">MM</abbr> order thing:
> 

Thanks, seems to be working fine.

Cheers,

I held off using this mod for a while because I didn't want to have to deal with a new fuel type, but I do really like the engines.

One request though, is it possible to have the liquid hydrogen fuel available in procedural tanks? Or am I better asking in the procedural parts thread?

There is a patch which should allow cryogenic tanks on procedural tanks.  If it's not working, then it's a bug.  Could you please do the following?

- In your GameData folder, delete ModuleManager.ConfigCache
- Start KSP and wait for it to get to the menu screen
- Find KSP.log (in your KSP root folder) and GameData/ModuleManager.ConfigCache and upload them somewhere we can see.

If you can provide that information, we should be able to debug the issue.

I see the issue.  [@Nertea](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/83952-nertea/) In this patch, it should be checking for Procedural Parts and NOT Modular Fuel tanks: [https://github.com/ChrisAdderley/CryoTanks/blob/master/GameData/CryoTanks/Patches/CryoTanksProceduralFuelTanks.cfg#L4](https://github.com/ChrisAdderley/CryoTanks/blob/master/GameData/CryoTanks/Patches/CryoTanksProceduralFuelTanks.cfg#L4)

So it should be @PART[procedural\*Liquid]:NEEDS[ProceduralParts&!ModularFuelTanks&!RealFuels]:FOR[CryoTanks]

Although the ProceduralParts part isn't strictly necessary because procedural\*Liquid should really only match procedural tanks anyway

Working on 1.2.1 modded career and figured I'd show off [@Nertea](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/83952-nertea/)'s awesome custom plume. Reason to download alone.

Now that KSP 1.2.2 is available, I have tested CryoEngines for KSP 1.2.1 on it; even if the loading screen message says that CryoEngines is no longer compatible with version 1.2.2, it seems that the mod is perfectly working. At least, I did not experience any issue.

If I am right, CryoEngines for KSP 1.2.2 may be just a minor revision.
Should the 2.5 Meter Tunguska Engine have a lower thrust than the Volcano which is half the size?

> 
> 
> 7 minutes ago, Montieth said:
> 
> 
> Should the 2.5 Meter Tunguska Engine have a lower thrust than the Volcano which is half the size?
> 

Haven't looked at the exact numbers but that sounds reasonable to me.  The Tunguska is an upper stage engine that uses a very large nozzle to get good I<sub>sp</sub>.  The Volcano is a lower stage lifter that would need a smaller nozzle to work at sea level.

The turbo-machinery for each is about the same size - the nozzle and support structure makes up most of the size difference. It is also a balance trade-off between thrust and efficiency. If the upper stage engines were more powerful there would be little reason to use the lifter engines - it would be better to use the upper stage engines as ground-lit sustainers and strap some soilds on to get you off the ground.  Atmospheric pressure drops off fast enough that (at least in <abbr title="Real Solar System (mod)">RSS</abbr> scale games) it is often better to use a Vacuum engine quite low in the atmosphere - they often exceed the performance of lifter engines by 10,000m or so. Dirt-cheap SRBs can get you that high in under a minute.
Ahh, that makes sense. I hadn't realized it was an upper stage motor.
